abstract.p: This document defines the JSON schema for testing KDA-TwoStep SP800-56C implementations with the ACVP specification.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: This document defines the JSON schema for testing KDA-TwoStep SP800-56C implementations with the ACVP specification.

clause.title: Introduction
clause.p: The Automated Crypto Validation Protocol (ACVP) defines a mechanism to automatically verify the cryptographic implementation of a software or hardware crypto module. The ACVP specification defines how a crypto module communicates with an ACVP server, including crypto capabilities negotiation, session management, authentication, vector processing and more. The ACVP specification does not define algorithm specific JSON constructs for performing the crypto validation. A series of ACVP sub-specifications define the constructs for testing individual crypto algorithms. Each sub-specification addresses a specific class of crypto algorithms. This sub-specification defines the JSON constructs for testing KDA-TwoStep SP800-56C implementations using ACVP.

clause.title: Supported KDA TwoStep
clause.p: The following key derivation algorithms MAY be advertised by the ACVP compliant cryptographic module:

clause.title: Test Types and Test Coverage
clause.p: The ACVP server performs a set of tests on the KDAs specific to the KAS protocol in order to assess the correctness and robustness of the implementation. A typical ACVP validation session SHALL require multiple tests to be performed for every supported permutation of KDA capabilities. This section describes the design of the tests used to validate implementations of KDA algorithms.

clause.title: Test Types
clause.p: There are two test types for KDA testing:

li.p: “AFT” — Algorithm Function Test. In the AFT test mode, the IUT SHALL act as a party in the Key Agreement with the ACVP server. The server SHALL generate and provide all necessary information for the IUT to perform a successful key agreement; both the server and IUT MAY act as party U/V.

“VAL” — Validation Test. In the VAL test mode, The ACVP server MUST generate a complete (from both party U and party V’s perspectives) key agreement, and expects the IUT to be able to determine if that agreement is valid. Various types of errors MUST be introduced in varying portions of the key agreement process that the IUT MUST be able to detect and report on.

clause.title: Test Coverage
clause.p: The tests described in this document have the intention of ensuring an implementation is conformant to and .

li.p: SP 800-56C — 5 Two-Step Key Derivation. All functionality described in the specification is covered by ACVP testing.
SP 800-56Ar3 / SP 800-56Br2 — ASN.1 encoding for the KDA is not currently supported.

clause.title: Capabilities Registration
clause.p: ACVP requires crypto modules to register their capabilities. This allows the crypto module to advertise support for specific algorithms, notifying the ACVP server which algorithms need test vectors generated for the validation process. This section describes the constructs for advertising support of KDA-TwoStep SP800-56C algorithms to the ACVP server.

The algorithm capabilities MUST be advertised as JSON objects within the ‘algorithms’ value of the ACVP registration message. The ‘algorithms’ value is an array, where each array element is an individual JSON object defined in this section. The ‘algorithms’ value is part of the ‘capability_exchange’ element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification for more details on the registration message.

clause.title: Prerequisites
clause.p: Each algorithm implementation MAY rely on other cryptographic primitives. For example, RSA Signature algorithms depend on an underlying hash function. Each of these underlying algorithm primitives must be validated, either separately or as part of the same submission. ACVP provides a mechanism for specifying the required prerequisites:

Prerequisites, if applicable, MUST be submitted in the registration as the prereqVals JSON property array inside each element of the algorithms array. Each element in the prereqVals array MUST contain the following properties
A “valValue” of “same” SHALL be used to indicate that the prerequisite is being met by a different algorithm in the capability exchange in the same registration.
An example description of prerequisites within a single algorithm capability exchange looks like this

clause.title: Property Registration
clause.p: The KDA-TwoStep SP800-56C mode capabilities are advertised as JSON objects within a root “algorithm” object.
A registration SHALL use these properties:

tr.td: The algorithm testing revision to use.
The domain of values representing the min/max lengths of Z the implementation can support.
The length (in bits) of the largest derived keying material the implementation can produce (up to a max of 2048).
Should multi expansion runs of the KDA be tested (in addition to the single expansion tests)? Only applicable for

clause.title: Prerequisite Algorithms for KDA Validations
clause.p: Some algorithm implementations rely on other cryptographic primitives. For example, IKEv2 uses an underlying SHA algorithm. Each of these underlying algorithm primitives must be validated, either separately or as part of the same submission. ACVP provides a mechanism for specifying the required prerequisites:

tr.td: object with algorithm and valValue properties

clause.title: Two Step KDA Capabilities

tr.td: How the salt is determined (default being all 00s, random being a random salt).
The pattern used for fixedInfo construction.
The encoding type to use with fixedInfo construction. Note concatenation is currently supported. ASN.1 should be coming.
The strategy for running the KDA.
The macMode supported by the KDA.

CMAC-AES128, CMAC-AES192, CMAC-AES256, HMAC-SHA-1, HMAC-SHA2-224, HMAC-SHA2-256, HMAC-SHA2-384, HMAC-SHA2-512, HMAC-SHA2-512/224, HMAC-SHA2-512/256, HMAC-SHA3-224, HMAC-SHA3-256, HMAC-SHA3-384, HMAC-SHA3-512
The counter locations supported by the KDA.
none, before fixed data, after fixed data, before iterator
The counter lengths supported for the KDA.
Single range (of literal) expected. Registered value must support the L value provided.
The KDA supports an empty IV (feedback mode).
The KDA requires an empty IV (feedback mode).

clause.p: Note this capabilities object is very similar to the capability object from SP800-108.

clause.title: FixedInfoPatternConstruction
clause.p: IUTs MUST be capable of specifying how the FixedInfo is constructed for the KDA construction. Note that for the purposes of testing against the ACVP system, both uPartyInfo and vPartyInfo are REQUIRED to be registered within the fixed info pattern.
Pattern candidates:

li.p: uses the specified hex within “[]”. literal[0123456789ABCDEF] substitutes “0123456789ABCDEF” in place of the field
“optional” items such as ephemeralKey MUST be included when available for ACVP testing.
“optional” items such as ephemeralKey MUST be included when available for ACVP testing.
Random value chosen by ACVP server to represent the context.
Random value chosen by ACVP server to represent the algorithmId.
Random value chosen by ACVP server to represent the label.
The length of the derived keying material in bits, MUST be represented in 32 bits for ACVP testing.
A random value used to represent a secondary shared secret. Only applicable to .

clause.p: Example (Note that party U is the server in this case “434156536964”, party V is the IUT “a1b2c3d4e5”):
Evaluated as:

clause.title: Registration Example
Test Vectors
clause.p: The ACVP server provides test vectors to the ACVP client, which are then processed and returned to the ACVP server for validation. A typical ACVP validation test session would require multiple test vector sets to be downloaded and processed by the ACVP client. Each test vector set represents an individual algorithm defined during the capability exchange. This section describes the JSON schema for a test vector set used with KDA-TwoStep SP800-56C algorithms.

The test vector set JSON schema is a multi-level hierarchy that contains meta data for the entire vector set as well as individual test vectors to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements at the top level of the hierarchy.

table.name: Top Level Test Vector JSON Elements

tr.td: Algorithm defined in the capability exchange
Mode defined in the capability exchange
Array of test groups containing test data, see

clause.p: An example of this would look like this

clause.title: Test Groups JSON Schema
clause.p: The testGroups element at the top level in the test vector JSON object is an array of test groups. Test vectors are grouped into similar test cases to reduce the amount of data transmitted in the vector set. For instance, all test vectors that use the same key size would be grouped together. The Test Group JSON object contains meta data that applies to all test vectors within the group. The following table describes the KDA-TwoStep SP800-56C JSON elements of the Test Group JSON object

tr.td: Describes the operation the client should perform on the tests data
Describes the KDA configuration values used for the group
Describes the KDA configuration values used for single expansion groups.
Describes the KDA configuration values used for multi expansion groups.

clause.p: The ‘tgId’, ‘testType’ and ‘tests’ objects MUST appear in every test group element communicated from the server to the client as a part of a prompt. Other properties are dependent on which ‘testType’ the group is addressing.

clause.title: KDA Configuration JSON Schema
clause.p: Describes the KDA configuration for use under the test group.

tr.td: The type of KDA to use for the group.
The pattern used for constructing the fixedInfo.
The pattern used for constructing the fixedInfo.
The MAC function used in the KDA.
the bit length of keying material to derive from the KDA

clause.title: KDA Multi Expansion Configuration JSON Schema
clause.p: Describes the KDA Multi Expansion configuration for use under the test group.

tr.td: The type of KDA to use for the group.
The bit length of the salt.
The MAC function used in the KDA.
the bit length of keying material to derive from the KDA

clause.title: Test Case JSON Schema
clause.p: Each test group contains an array of one or more test cases. Each test case is a JSON object that represents a single test vector to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements for each KAS/KTS ECC test vector.

tr.td: Numeric identifier for the test case, unique across the entire vector set.
Object representing inputs into the KDA for single expansion tests.
Fixed information specific to party U for single expansion tests.
Fixed information specific to party V for single expansion tests.

clause.title: KDA Parameter JSON Schema
clause.p: KDA specific options used for the test case.

tr.td: The salt used for the test case.
The iv used for the test case.
The random “algorithID” used for the test case when applicable to the fixedInfo pattern.
The random “context” used for the test case when applicable to the fixedInfo pattern.
The random “label” used for the test case when applicable to the fixedInfo pattern.
shared secret z value to be used for the test case.
the bit length of keying material to derive from the KDA

clause.title: FixedInfo PartyU/V JSON Schema
clause.p: Fixed information that is included for party U/V for fixed info construction

tr.td: Ephemeral data (randomly) included as a part of the parties fixed info construction

clause.title: KDA Multi Expansion Parameter JSON Schema
clause.p: KDA specific options used for the test case.

table.name: KDF Multi Expansion Parameter JSON Object

tr.td: The salt used for the test case.
shared secret z value to be used for the test case.
the per iteration parameters for multi expansion

clause.title: KDA Multi Expansion IterationParameters JSON Schema
clause.p: The per multi expansion iteration specific parameters used within a test case.

table.name: KDF Multi Expansion IterationParameters JSON Object

tr.td: The length of keying material to derive for the current iteration.

The fixed information for the current iteration. Note that does not go into detail regarding how this per iteration fixed info should be constructed, but it obviously needs to be different each iteration.

clause.title: Example Test Vectors JSON
clause.p: The following is a example JSON object for KAS-FFC test vectors sent from the ACVP server to the crypto module.

clause.title: Test Vector Responses
clause.p: After the ACVP client downloads and processes a vector set, it MUST send the response vectors back to the ACVP server. The following table describes the JSON object that represents a vector set response.

The testGroups section is used to organize the ACVP client response in a similar manner to how it receives vectors. Several algorithms SHALL require the client to send back group level properties in their response. This structure helps accommodate that.

The testCase section is used to organize the ACVP client response in a similar manner to how it receives vectors. Several algorithms SHALL require the client to send back group level properties in their response. This structure helps accommodate that.
The following table describes the JSON object that represents a test case response for a KDA-TwoStep SP800-56C.

tr.td: Was the provided dkm valid? Only valid for the “VAL” test type.
The derived keying material. Provided by the IUT for “AFT” test type test cases.

clause.p: Here is an abbreviated example of the response

clause.title: Example Test Vectors Response JSON
Security Considerations
clause.p: There are no additional security considerations outside of those outlined in the ACVP document.

annex.title: Terminology
annex.p: For the purposes of this document, the following terms and definitions apply.

verbal-definition.p: JSON sent from the server to the client describing the tests the client performs
The initial request from the client to the server describing the capabilities of one or several algorithm, mode and revision combinations
JSON sent from the client to the server in response to the prompt
An individual unit of work within a prompt or response
A collection of test cases that share similar properties within a prompt or response
A collection of test groups under a specific algorithm, mode, and revision
JSON sent from the server to the client that specifies the correctness of the response

bibitem.title: Key words for use in RFCs to Indicate Requirement Levels

organization.name: Internet Engineering Task Force

abstract.p: In many standards track documents several words are used to signify the requirements in the specification. These words are often capitalized. This document defines these words as they should be interpreted in IETF documents. This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.

organization.name: Internet Engineering Task Force

abstract.p: This document defines the “xml2rfc” version 3 vocabulary: an XML-based language used for writing RFCs and Internet-Drafts. It is heavily derived from the version 2 vocabulary that is also under discussion. This document obsoletes the v2 grammar described in RFC 7749.

bibitem.title: Ambiguity of Uppercase vs Lowercase in RFC 2119 Key Words

organization.name: Internet Engineering Task Force

abstract.p: RFC 2119 specifies common key words that may be used in protocol specifications. This document aims to reduce the ambiguity by clarifying that only UPPERCASE usage of the key words have the defined special meanings.
